About me

Rationally reprogram enzyme catalysis by advancing computational enzymology predictive and systematic with the power of natural evolution. (My Career Goal)

Follow @Wen_Jun_Xie

Trained as a theoretical chemist,

nurtured from computational biology,

developed to be a fan of enzyme.

• Postdoc with Arieh Warshel (Nobel laureate), USC, 2020-now

• Postdoc, MIT, 2017-2020

• Visting Student, Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research, 2016

• PhD in Chemistry, Peking University, 2017

• BSc in Chemistry and Mathematics, Peking University, 2012

enzyme

Enzymes are remarkable biocatalysts that tremendously accelerate chemical reactions. Our knowledge of enzymes is incomplete, if not poor, despite extensive studies through several generations of scientists. We believe learning from nature is inescapable to advance enzymology further. Recently, we connected enzyme evolution and enzyme catalysis, two important phenomena at contrasting timescales; the connection provides the first-ever systematic method to predict mutation effects on enzyme activity. The prediction suggests a rational way to engineer enzymes. Besides, we found that natural evolution underlies the laboratory evolution of designer enzymes whose scaffold is obtained from natural proteins. Moreover, we revealed how commercialized covalent inhibitors for kinases achieve selectivity over evolutionarily-related sequences. Each of our studies has many implications and applications. Collaborating with biochemists, we are starting to have experimental results. Fox example, we recently demonstrated the high success rate of our method in enzyme design (manuscript available). Stay tuned!

chromatin folding and epigenetics

Why human has multiple cell types with the same DNA sequence? Because of the epigenome! We aim to understand the establishement of epigenetic information using data-driven approaches. Some of our predictions has been recently confirmed in experiment. The epigenome also affects chromatin folding, which plays critical roles in genome function. Our analysis of single-cell chromatin imaging data unraveled the phase separation mechanism caused by epigenome patterns. Importantly, we are able to quantify the energy landscape of chromatin folding using machine learning and statistical physics.

protein in solutions

Solutions are essential for life. Their properties at the molecular level can be best studied using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. We combined ab-initio MD simulations, pump-probe spectroscopy, and NMR to learn how TMAO interacts with urea in marine animals. We employed force-field MD simulations to explain the salt effects on protein structure and counterion effects on the ice nucleation on polyelectrolytes. These studies prompted us to propose a simple theory for the famous Hofmeister series. In another study, we also demonstrated how the electrolyte solution affects interleukin release through the GSDMD pore during inflammation.
